text: During 333 years the Spanish ruled the Philippines.
That colonial period in the Asian archipelago lasted just as long as in the nations in Latin America.
And yet Philippines is not a Spanish-speaking country.
What happened so that Spanish was lost? And… was it really lost? We will tell you about it in this video.
First of all, there are two official languages in the Philippines.
One, as you may already assume, is Filipino, which is a standardized version of Tagalog
and Tagalog is the indigenous language of much of the island of Luzon, which is the largest
and most populated island in the country, where the capital is, Manila. And the other official language, and this may surprise you,
is English. Because for half a century,
between 1898 and 1946, the Philippines was a colony of the United States. We will tell you more about this later.
But although it is not spoken, the influence of Spanish is present today in the daily life of Filipinos.
It is estimated that 30% of Tagalog comes from Spanish,
and this is noticeable above all in the vocabulary that has to do with the table and food,
clothes, the days of the week or the months of the year ...
You will surely have no problem understanding these words in Tagalog, for example:
And one of the most surprising things is the mark that the Spanish left
in the names and surnames. Take, for example, those of these members of the Philippine government.
As you can see, the Spanish influence is evident on a day-to-day basis. But what happened to the language?
Fernando de Magallanes was the first European to arrive in the archipelago, in 1521, and he named it
with the name Las Felipinas, honouring the King Felipe II of Spain.
And when the Spaniards settled there, in 1565, they found -as in America-,
an enormous linguistic wealth: bear in mind that even today around 100 to 180 languages
are spoken in the Philippines, depending on how they are classified.
And as in America, during the following centuries the Spanish Crown wanted Castilian
to prevail as the language of its domains. Now, colonization was closely linked to evangelization,
but in the Philippines there were few missionaries and they soon realized that
with Spanish they could not go very far. So they learned the local languages to spread Christianity.
And based in their experience in America,
they chose certain languages called “general languages”, which were those used by different
peoples to communicate with each other, as it happened in Mexico with Nahuatl and in Peru with Quechua.
And that is how the missionaries used mainly Tagalog, in the Manila area,
and Cebuano on the island of Cebu and the islands of the central Philippines, called Visayas.
And over the following centuries they consolidated what today is an indelible mark
of the Spanish: Catholicism. Not only is the Philippines today one of the only two
predominantly Catholic nations in Asia - along with East Timor, but also,
with its more than 106 million inhabitants, it is the third country in the world with the most Catholics,
after Brazil and Mexico. And then what happened to the Spanish?
Over the centuries Spanish became a language confined to a social elite.
In the villages, if there was no priest, probably no one
would have had any contact with Spanish. By the 19th century, Spanish was the language
of the administration and the one spoken by the highest social class of the Filipino population,
but it was not the one spoken by the majority of the people. And just like in America,
in the Philippines the independence movement towards the end of the 19th century spoke Spanish,
only that rebellion against the Spaniards, which lasted for years, did not materialize and in the end
the Filipinos were unexpectedly under the rule of another power. Which one? U.S.
And why? Because in 1898 the United States got involved in the Cuban War of Independence.
That caused the outbreak of the Spanish-American War, which the Americans
won in just over three months, and after which they kept the possessions that Spain had in the Pacific,
including the Philippine Islands. For three years the Philippines fought against
the new colonial power in the Philippine-American War
which was the first war of national liberation of the 20th century.
But they lost. And do you know what was one of the first measures that the United States
adopted after the war ended? Well, they sent two boats loaded with teachers to teach English
to Filipino children from all over the archipelago. Now, the great paradox in this story is that
it was precisely during this time that Spanish reached its peak in the Philippines.
Despite the American plan, Spanish was the language of parliamentarians and the one used
by many Filipino authors who wrote super interesting literary works. In addition,
many newspapers and publications in Spanish were created as a symbol of resistance to the Americans.
But, -and here is the great nuance-, that does not mean that everyone spoke Spanish,
it was still a language of the elites, so it cannot really be said that the language was lost.
So when finally on July 4, 1946, the Philippines was officially recognized
as an independent nation by the US, the official language that they adopted was English,
which was that of the immediately preceding colonial power. Before finishing, I will share another interesting fact
and that is that the Spanish language that arrived in the Philippines had many influences from Mexico,
because the Spanish assigned the government of the archipelago to the Viceroyalty of New Spain,
whose capital was Mexico City, which was a lot closer than Madrid.
But in addition, there is a Creole language called Chavacano that is still spoken today,
especially in the Zamboanga peninsula, in the southwest of the archipelago.
And this language was born precisely from the coexistence of Filipinos, Spaniards and Mexicans in the seventeenth century.
So today we are going to end this video with a little bit of Chavacano. But first,
if you liked the video, I invite you to subscribe to the channel. I'm leaving now, or as they would say in Chavacano, “anda ya yo”.
